author: Nickseidel843

description.text:
When I had the privilege of meeting nophead and his good lady last month, one of the questions I was asked was whether I had made lots of useful things for my wife. Reluctantly, I had to admit that I had only made her a keyring, so far.
My opportunity came yesterday when she asked me for help with a specific problem. My wife enjoys making things as well but her filaments are more of the sewing and knitting variety. Recently, she has been experimenting with a kind of knitting called intarsia, which calls for lots of different coloured strands of wool to be in use at the same time to build a picture. You'll get the idea from this video http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l7G4yzCzpHk (skip to 3:30 to see the bobbins).
I designed the basic shape in Tinkercad and then did a bit of tweaking in Blender.
She was delighted with the result and now understands how useful my expensive new toy can really be.

I printed mine with two perimeters and two solid layers to give a bit of weight. They are 3 mm thick, so 10 layers at 0.3 mm layer height.
I added the holes, a) to save plastic, b) to reduce the weight, and c) to allow the wool to be tucked through at the start of winding.
I can fit four of them on my Mendel90 but found that manual placement was more efficient than just printing multiple copies in this case.

comments.text: My wife just got into knitting big time!  This is great Rich!  I will print this up once my machine is back together :)
comments.author: idolcrasher

description.text:
This is work in progress!!! UPDATE: on request a set of STL are uploaded. They are only at BETA stage. Please do not ask features or corrections. Instead edit your copy of the 123D files. A mini electric ducted fan (EDF) designed around the E-flite BL180 - 3000KV brushless motor. Look how small it is. (2s Lipo, 2A continuous, 3A for 10 seconds max.) Main features are:
  • Center of momentum - Impeller is mounted on the outside of the BL rotor. This is not common, as most EDF's use a "inrunner" motor.
  • Load distribution - Impeller is a "pusher" and distributes the load on the whole rim of the BL rotor. If it was a "puller" it would put huge stress on the 3 screws.
    • First printed impeller was running without any vibrations!!! Designed in Autodesk 123D.

Impeller must be printed with 100% fill for strength.
Use support material. My current settings:
First layer: 0,25mm
Next layers: 0,15mm
PLA at 180 deg. C
Bed at 57 deg. C
"Slow speed" / Cooling fan with open window and freezing outside / tweaking and tweaking and tweaking of all params in Slic3r. PS. You might want to process the STL file in meshlab prior to slicing.

Okay, this is bit of a print challenge due to needing supports and challenges with the orientation for the flower. I tried printing it facing up with supports under but it took unnecessarily long and result wasn't as good as when tilting the model to the side so the stem and petals touch the printing bed. This is the default rotation I uploaded the model with, it will still need some supports. I used 0.1mm layer height for the flower.

Then comes the stamen, which utilizes bridging to create strings of filament you can then shape by using a hair dryer or hot air gun. This needs to be printed at 0.2mm if using the default scale.

And lastly the branch simply needs supports under it, nothing too special about it. I included connectors for the flowers but they are kinda weak and I managed to break one off, you will need glue. Or you can just replace them with thin enough nails for example that you can embed in the branch by heating it with soldering iron, as I had to do for one of the flowers.
Zawsze mi pękają gówniane plastikowe obudowy. Ta powinna trzymać nieco dłużej.

title: Lasercut Paint Rack For Eye Dropper Style Paints (180 Bottle Storage)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
MDF paint rack that I designed for a few hobbyist friends with large paint collections, based on others I had seen around the Internet. This design holds 180 eyedropper style paint bottles and could easily be modified by anyone with a modicum of Inkscape or similar vector manipulation skills. I have a similar sized paint rack for paint pots that I will release into the wilds of Thingiverse later, once I have adjusted spacing on some of the components.

This design is formatted for cutting on two 3mm MDF sheets cut to (Arch C) 24" x 18" - which I cut on the bed of an Epilog Helix. I have provided the PDF and a SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is, which you can customize to your own needs.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. If you liked it enough to download it I'd appreciate a LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

comments.text: Designed them for 17ml Vallejo paints http://www.acrylicosvallejo.com/en_US/model-color/family/15 which I recall my making the recesses just slight;y larger than their 1" diameter, depth is another issue altogether. https://www.reddit.com/r/minipainting/comments/38tju8/paint_bottle_dimensions/

remixed_from.author: bernbout
remixed_from.title: Geeetech Al Anti Z Wobble Remix

title: Z wobble stabilizer for Prusa based designs

description.text:
The threaded rods on a lot of cheaper printers are slightly bent, this creates a banding pattern on the print because the carriage wobbles.
This design counters this by decoupling the carriage and the threaded rod.

Based on this design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1431036
In contrast, my design helps wobble in both the x and the y direction.

The instructions are the same as for that one, put a nut in the print at the bottom and have it on the threaded rod.
It then will support the x carriage, which is now no longer attached in a fixed way to the bent threaded rod.

I recommend printing without supports as they would be hard to remove from the center nut area.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

A somewhat higher infill might be good because the full weight of the carriage is resting on the print.

description.text:
This is a Sun Shade & protection bumper for my ebike LCD Display.
The Display measures 95mmx65mmx13mm.
Print in ABS at 35%.
Supports No
Raft No.

This is a work in progress...

Update 26032017:- This didn't start out as a remix, but ended up remixing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1938817 to sort my design out as it was not robust enough. I removed the the clips from the original design as they just broke off too easily. Gloop ((acetone mixed with ABS) is needed to seal it and finish better, it should also make it tighter, so it doesn't come off too easily. This is a work in progress so may design a back plate for it, that encases it completely.....

I Printed this in 2 parts so no supports were needed.
Top part printed in ABS at 15% fill at 0.2.
Bottom part printed in ABS at 35% fill at 0.2.
Glued the two pieces together using gloop (acetone mixed with glow in the dark green ABS).

Paused the top print after about 45 minutes to change the ABS colour from glow in the dark green to black mid print :-)

description.text:
The Dremel attachments 566 and 565 feature a port that to me looks like a attachment point for a vacuum cleaner (2nd picture). I found however that Dremel does not sell anything that connects to it. So, I decided to make something that does!

The attachment posted connects to a, in my case, Karcher vacuum cleaner hose and should fit other brands as well. The inner diameter is 35.4mm and tapers in to 34.4mm to provide a snug fit to the vacuum cleaner hose.

I do recommend to not run the vacuum cleaner at it's highest speed as the attachment can start to whistle due to the small diameter of the dust collection port.

I also posted the part that just fits in the dust collection port so anyone can create their own attachment. It will print in about 3 minutes so it's a nice piece to do a test fit with.

The parts were designed in Sketchup, skp-files are also included.

Printer:

Vertex K8400

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm layers

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I used only support above the print bed.

The Mowi Printer is a foldable 3d printer, It can print big prints with two materials. Folded flat it is small and easy to take along. Put your files on a sd card and you do not even need a laptop to print. You can make this printer yourself. The frame is made from lasercut Birch Plywood. All other non standard parts are 3d printed.
All information can be found on http://reprap.org/wiki/Mowi_printer.
Up-to-date files to start making can be found on https://github.com/Mowi/MowiPrinter Video is at http://youtu.be/pdC9KxD-kWQ

comments.text: Deciding mostly between builing the Mowi and Foldarap, I prefer the dual direct drive of the Mowie and the larger print area, but I'm somewhat concerned. How stable/rigid is the Mowi compared to some other printers? Does it have any issues shifting while printing?
comments.author: Jedimaster711

comments.text:
Hi Jedimaster,
as long as you are not taking it of your table during the print there are no problems, in version 3 i included some hendels that keep it pretty stable but probably not enough for moving during printing. If you do not fold and unfold it often you could also put screws through both bottom plates which makes it really sturdy but could be quite a hassle to insert often. The mowiprinter is still in development but I would love to have some more people thinking about solutions :) Version 3 still has some other issues that i am trying to solve now. Let me know if you want more info!
comments.author: Jedimaster711

comments.text: also curious, steppers often come in 5 packs, will they still fit ok if i have 5 large motors and 1 small? or 6 large?
comments.author: mowi

comments.text:
Hi Jedimaster, You could also use big steppers for the extruder. You will loose a bit of the x-axis movement but at the moment my x can move more than 200mm anyway. You will probably need to change the position of the magnet for the x endstop.
By the way, at the moment I am working on a new arrangment for the extruder head. I am looking into using the dual chimera hotend. This is way cheaper than the two hotends i used before and you can easily swap the nozzles

comments.text:
Hi,
Don't worry :) I managed to somehow understand what you did there but there are many strange decisions in the design XD so I'm remixing it my way for my personal use, because i don't understand really well the licence that you use.
comments.author: mowi

comments.text:
Hi Ark,
Great that you managed. Yes, I am sure there are a lot of strange decisions, i tried to get a big printing volume while keeping a small transport volume. At the same time i wanted to use mostly standard components and not a lot of parts. It is always difficult to find a nice balance between all the requirements. Sometimes i had to do really strange things so i would have enough clearance with the other parts. At other times i probably just made strange choices. I am sorry that is not always that easy to assemble. I am working on the next generation now and i would love to see your adjustments too. I think the frame can easily be done with 5mm birch plywood. I have a parametric inventor file where you only need to change one parameter. Hopefully I worked neatly and all the rest stays put. I can send it to you if you would like. Just give me your email in a private message. The display sides should be no problem either but you will run into trouble with the extruder. You'll either have to change it or wait for the new one which uses cheaper mk8 hotends and will be easier to change to 5mm. I didn't test it yet though so i am not sure it will work.
About the license, I used the same license as the printers i used for inspiration like prusa i3 etc. I would really appreciate it if you could share your modifications too.
comments.author: ark

comments.text:
Sure :) I was doing it in autocad line by line, so you'll recieve my message soon :)
I'm mostly changing printed parts and frame to fit NEMA17 48mm (more usual in spanish shops) , and I will design a single extruder after i mount all the frame and see if my decisions are right XD

title: Tank Miniatures for Ogre Designer's Edition

description.text:
Last weekend I was re-exposed to the game Ogre. My friend got the new Ogre Designer's Edition (go out and get it now, before they run out) which has some great cardboard cut out Ogres, but only flat pieces of cardboard for the other units. Playing with the flats for tanks was a bit unsatisfying. So I dug around in my game closet and found my old minis for the game. It seems I only have Combine units and could use some for the enemy.
Here's my start on some really low resolution versions of the Panuropean units. The idea is to replace to cardboard flats with versions that can just be tossed into the box without worrying about breakage.
http://www.sjgames.com/ogre/products/ogre6e/
The material presented here is my original creation, intended for use with the Ogre system from Steve Jackson Games. This material is not official and is not endorsed by Steve Jackson Games. Ogre is a registered trademark of Steve Jackson Games. All rights are reserved by SJ Games. This material is used here in accordance with the SJ Games online policy.

The models were created in Tinkercad. Printed with 1 shell, 10% infill, and 0.2 mm layer height on a Replicator.
The barrels of the Heavy and Superheavy tanks did not print well, so I replaced them with jumbo paperclips cut down to size. The diameter is a little smaller than I'd like, but I'm not really going for hyper realism or detail.
The Mobile Howitzer needs to be re-done. The barrel does not print well. I will probably replace it with a toothpick.
Models:
https://tinkercad.com/things/56pOoDhj2Wr-jaeger-heavy-tank
https://tinkercad.com/things/gFoiHdlF9bz-thor-superheavy-tank
https://tinkercad.com/things/22ZmaGptLq7-cosack-lgev
https://tinkercad.com/things/4k7xozUCj8N-gev
https://tinkercad.com/things/7bg9h2bK1yi-missle-tank-tank
https://tinkercad.com/things/5ROMFB7znfR-mobile-howitzer

title: Ring Revolver Toy maintenant il lance des progectiles , Now he launches projectiles
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Voila la version Toy du Ring Revolver , un petit clin d’œil a Cyclone qui me demandait sur mon premier modèle si il lançait les projectiles . c'est chose faite et en prime la petit vidéo explicative et maladroite ( c'est ma premier fois ) , qu'il m'avait réclamer .
J'ai placer la pièce " Garde Au Corps Vide " pour ceux qui aimeraient là personnaliser , et ceux qui n'aime pas cette pièce préféreront celle appeler " Faux Garde Au Corps ".
les projectiles partent très vite ... dans les yeux cela dois être vraiment désagréable alors faite attention . nos chers animaux de compagnie ne sont pas des cibles , laissez les tranquille .
faite attention aussi a vos petits chérubins de mois de 36 mois .
la vidéo est en français , je suis malheureusement pas bilingue mais je pense qu'elle est assez explicite .
pour le réaliser il vous faudra récupérer 3 ressort de pierre a briquet , je préfère ceux des briquet Bic grand modèle a molette car ils sont long et ont un diamètre de 2.5mm environ .
vous devrez couper a l'aide d'une petite pince coupante les taille suivantes :

  • 1 de 18 mm ( Chien )
    -1 de 7 mm ( Gâchette )
  • 6 de 11 a 12 mm ( Barillet)
    supprimez les spires trop serrés a chaque extrémité
    vous aurez besoin de 2 petits bouts de filament 1.75mm de 11mm et 10mm environ
    et il vous faudra une vis M2.5 mm de diamètre et 5 mm de long Mini et 10 mm Maxi .
    Pour le barillet munissez vous d'un forer de 4.5 mm pour enlever les éventuelles bavures et vérifiez que les projectiles passe librement dans les trous . vous devrez surement aussi nettoyer le passage de téton du projectile a l'aide d'une lame de cutteur ou une lime fine genre lime a ongles .
    pour le corps de l'anneau vous pouvez aussi dégager , avec un forer de 3 mm , le trou de logement du ressort de gâchette .

traduit du français avec google

Here is the Toy version of the Ring Revolver, a little wink to Cyclone who asked me about my first model if he threw the projectiles. It is done and as a bonus the little explanatory video and awkward (this is my first time), that he had to claim.
I have placed the piece "Garde Au Corps Vide" for those who would like to customize there, and those who do not like this piece will prefer the one called "Faux Garde Au Corps".
The projectiles leave very quickly ... in the eyes this must be really unpleasant then be careful. Our dear pets are not targets, leave them alone.
Also pay attention to your little cherubs of month of 36 months.
The video is in French, I am unfortunately not bilingual but I think it is quite explicit.

To realize it you will have to recover 3 spring of lighter stone, I prefer those of the lighter Bic big model has wheel because they are long and have a diameter of 2.5mm approximately.
You will have to cut using a small cutter the following size:

  • 1 of 18 mm (Dog)
    -1 of 7 mm (Trigger)
  • 6 from 11 to 12 mm (Barrel)
    Remove loose turns at each end .
    You will need 2 small pieces of 1.75mm filament of 11mm and 10mm approximately .
    And you will need a screw M2.5 mm diameter and 5 mm long Mini and 10 mm Maxi.
    For drums, drill a 4.5 mm drill to remove any burrs and check that the projectiles pass freely through the holes. You may also need to clean the projectile projection using a knife blade or a fine nail file.
    For the body of the ring you can also clear, with a 3 mm drill, the hole of housing of the trigger spring

Translated from French with google

YOUTUBE : https://youtu.be/HAW3Y51do6M

Rafts:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 a 0.3 mm

Infill:

35 %

Notes:

pour la clavette et la gâchette je préfère les imprimer en PLA pour le reste vous pourrez l'imprimer en ABS OU autre matière .
j'utilise une buse de 0.3 mm et j'ai imprimer avec une hauteur de couche de 0.1 mm bien plus joli au final .
imprimez les projectiles a 100% de remplicge et sans support car il remplirai la partie creuse
les pièces " Barillet" et "Chien" devront être pivoter de 180° sur l'axe des X ou Y .
les pièces " Anneau Corps" et Chien seront a imprimer avec des support , j'ai posté des photos montrant ou et comment je les place , mais chacun fera a sa convenance .

Bonne impression , bon montage et amusez vous bien .

For the key and the trigger I prefer to print them in PLA for the rest you can print it in ABS or other matter.
I use a nozzle of 0.3 mm and I print with a layer height of 0.1 mm much more beautiful in the final.
Print the projectiles at 100% fill and without support because it will fill the hollow part.
The "Barrel" and "Dog" pieces must be rotated by 180 ° on the X or Y axis.
The pieces "Ring Body" and Dog will be printed with support, I posted photos showing or and how I place them, but everyone will do at his convenience.

Good impression, good assembly and have fun.

print_settings.Notes:: Make sure the chute is to the left or right on Mendel (Průša) style printers, or the y axis acceleration force would work to tear it loose.

description.text:
I’ve designed a new tea portioner that works a bit better. This uses less material, and maybe some people prefer this shape.

Quickly measure the right amount of tea leaves for one pot, or other granular materials where you need the same amount every day:

  • Place the funnel on the measuring cup. There is a right way, with the wider brim of the funnel on the flat surface of the cup, but with the funnel in another direction it should work well, too.
  • Pour in the tea leaves until the cup is a bit over full.
  • Slide off the funnel, striking the measuring cup and pouring the extra tea back in its tin over the chute.
  • The measure now contains the right amount of tea. Pour it into the filter or teapot. I use my funnel and stand for this.

The STL files included are for 44 cm³ (44 ml) and 55 cm³ (55 ml), the right amount of rooibos tea for my two teapots, 1 dm³ (1 l) and 1.25 dm³ (1.25 l). For other sizes use the customizer. When you have a mass, look up the density in the FAO list, elsewhere, or measure yourself.

The “American customary units” in the customizer is a bit of a joke, or my pet peeve.
Practically, Americans should look up the millilitres per teaspoon &c. in this list, and visit metric4us at their leisure after they printed their portioner.

Of course there’s nothing wrong with using measuring spoons or scoops like things 682146 or 619626. Except that the designer seems to think that 29.5735295625 cm³ or 14.7867647825 cm³ are useful units of measurement, and won’t discourage Americans – and Britons – from that silly habit. I still prefer this thing because tilting a tea tin is easier than filling a measuring spoon, especially if their is barely enough tea in the tin for one pot.

Instead of rafts, you can use a brim.
The brim or raft is only needed for the portioner bit. The chute may fall over during printing unless it sticks to the print bed well.

Make sure the chute is to the left or right on Mendel (Průša) style printers, or the y axis acceleration force would work to tear it loose.

I started with out with Soren Furbo box. There isn’t much code from it left, but the idea is still there, so to speak.

This part is also available at github. When the version here is ever updated, look at the repo there for older
versions.

• PLA seems to be better suited for food use than ABS, so you should use that. Or maybe PETG
  • You should probably clean your nozzle once, to get rid of mineral oil and other residues.
  • When you use an oiler, use a suitable oil. Maybe a vegetable oil or something like Ballistol oil.
  • The food comes into contact with the printed parts for only a short time, and it is usually dry, so it should hardly be effected at all.

These two articles shed some more light on the issue:

  • 10 things you need to know about 3D printing & food safety
  • Food Safe Video

In the end, it is up to you. I can take no responsibility.

This is a long version of the excellent hot end wrench: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2049806

I extended the arms to allow using the tool from the back, as I have a fan blocking the front of my hot ends. When combined with my heat shield, it allows me to change nozzles without disassembling anything.

Print with polycarbonate or other high temperature material. I heat my hotends up to 140 when removing the nozzles. This prevents the tool from melting or deforming.

title: Raise3D N2 heat shield and fan mount

description.text:
This is a combination heat shield and fan mount for the Raise3D N2/N2 Plus. This version only works with the V2 head. This is a remix of the excellent front fan mount by Sylus:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2102446

I got tired of having to remove my insulation wrappers around the hotends every time I wanted to change nozzles, so I designed this heat shield. It effectively blocks the hotend heat from affecting your prints, while also providing a fan.

To change nozzles without any disassembly, just use my modified hotend tool: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2183719. Heat your hotends to 140, insert the tool from behind the hotends and unscrew the nozzle. No more disassembly needed! Just remember to unload your old filament completely before removing the old nozzle. You want to ensure the isolation tube is completely clean before changing nozzles.

To print, use polycarbonate or other high temperature filament using .25 layer height. I used 25% infill to reduce weight. I positioned the model with the back of the shield (not the bottom) touching the base. This prevented the slicer from putting support material inside the fan air channel.

After printing, I used 1" kapton tape and covered both sides of the shield with 3-4 layers, then cut out the nozzle holes and air vent. The kapton is really only needed on the inside, but having it on both sides helps prevent filament from sticking to the hotends.

The fan I used is the same as the one Sylus used in his original design here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2102446

I got it on Amazon: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B015S5XFJE/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

description.text:
This board is a part of the 3D printed version of the miniMO modular synthesizer, an open source and open hardware project also hosted on Github.

The board has 15 terminal strips and a rail on each side. I designed it because I couldn't find any commercial models of this size with side rails.

To print the board, use a small (0.25mm) nozzle, and print it upside down, that is, with the grid against the printing surface. The metal clips should fit in place without much trouble; they might protrude a little bit at the bottom but in my experience that's never been a problem.

I have used several of these boards in the various versions of the synthesizer since 2014 (see above), and the circuits I've assembled on them have always held fine, even after transoceanic flights.

The 3D model was designed with wings3D.

remixed_from.author: noen
remixed_from.title: MP Select Mini Z-Axis Tapered Coupler

description.text:
I managed to snap one of the nuts on my original, and I didn't really like how you had to crank on both in order to tighten either. So I stretched it out and added a hex nut on the coupler itself and beefed up both nuts.

There is an extended hole inside on the side for the threaded rod that allows it to go all the way though, instead of lifting the rod up into the extruder motor.

A bit of a brain fart during design of the coupler made the hex not an actual standard size, so it would be best to use an adjustable wrench for it. If I need to make any other adjustments I'll fix that.

I put a small nylon washer on the motor shaft first to help prevent any up and down play in the motor.

Still in testing and would appreciate some feedback if you try it out.

*Edit 5-6-17: It appeared that original coupler had some missing geometry. If you're having issues with it breaking try the Coupler_Fixed.stl

description.text:
So, my Cable Catch for the Micro has been a modest hit both here and on Pinshape, but let the record show I am not one to rest on my laurels and that art is never truly finished, only abandoned.
A user by the name of philipmalone had brought to my attention that the design does not work for PLA or ABS-R filaments. This is a perfectly good and fair point. I may use the Tough Ink almost exclusively, but it's not for everyone.
This is a pair of modified versions of the cable catch that will favor solid filaments. I got pretty lucky with my print here; it was perfectly snug on that corner of the frame, but your mileage may vary.
I didn't bother printing the second version, but since it's just a retooling of the first, your results should be about the same.

Printer:

M3D Micro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

medium/low

Infill:

FULL

Notes:

The ones pictured were made using a raft, partly because of some ventilation issues causing prints to warp prematurely (I'll be making an enclosure before too long) and also because it's not the most flattering shade of red and I'm trying to use it up.

The Pacifier

The Supercatch is all one piece and fairly straightforward, but the Pacifier is going to involve getting your hands dirty... and a bit sticky if you're not careful.

Fair Warning: barring any chisels or hammers or diving boots, fastening the Nuk onto the power cable is an "All Sales Final" sort of affair.

You've got two options;
1) Glue the halves together over the cable and simply let it slide up and down the cord, or
2) if you don't want anything left to chance, you can gently coat the inside of the Nuk's barrel with a thin layer of glue to hold the cable permanently in place.

Also, bear in mind I'm using a stock version of the power supply that came with my printer. I've heard some people's wall warts lack the M3D logo on the back and look different from mine. I seriously doubt this will lead to any serious discrepancies in cable thickness, but I do suggest inspecting the STL file first before you get going.

Tinkercad

Now that 123D is no longer with us, I've had to migrate a lot of my design work to Tinkercad. Fusion360 is fine, but doesn't have the same feel or convenience as what I'm used to. I mean, Tinkercad runs on a Chromebook.

Following James Bruton, I see in episode 7 for Robot X that one of the drill motors failed where the gearbox joins the motor. I suspect that failure was from a lack of support. These parts fit this drill motor gearbox assembly and cradle it well: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0057I2Y54/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1 Hoping to avoid that same failure...

0.2 layers, 5 perimeters, 5 top, 5 bottom, 0.25 infill

4/27/17 Added MotorMountHolder.stl a wrap around box that encases the Full2Motor sectiions. MotorThigh.stl and MotorThighFlip.stl are self contained with the mount built in for a slimmer profile.

title: UM2(+) filament spool side hanger with UM connector

description.text:
Use any spool holder with "UM2 connector" with this. Sits in the middle of the UM2(+) side panel. Tested with PLA, easily carries 2kg XL spools. Other materials might bend more. Can be fixed with the case screw on top, but not necessary.
Split in two parts to fit the build plate. Screw the two pieces together, with 2x 10mm M3 screws and 2 M3 nuts. Careful that the screws to not stick out on the back side, they might scratch the UM side panel. Eventually use a file to shorten them 0.5mm.
Note the design is made for 0.4mm nozzle and for tight fit. Printing with 0.8mm nozzle might result in much tighter fit or even not fit of the top hanger or the UM connector.
I am currently using two of them, one on each side panel, to feed my new Bondtech feeders. See photos.

title: Sintron i3 X Axis Tension kit

description.text:
The idler bearings on the Sintron i3 clone are tied into the X gantry right side. Also, the X-axis tension is only adjustable by how you tie the belt into the X carriage. If you want a nice high belt tension, it tends to pull the right side gantry in along the rods, causing your Z axis rods to bow in and bind up.

I designed this to replace this whole silly setup and take advantage of the ~10mm of extra X rod length in my kit.

After installing these Things, you will be able to run the X tension much higher, and the X gantry right side will be able to float and self-adjust for minimum friction in the Z axis.

To assemble:

  • insert two flanged 5 x 10 x 4 bearings into the idler holder as shown. You'll need an M5 bolt and nut to act as a shaft.
  • insert an M4 "nylock" locking nut in the nut capture cavity in the end of the idler holder.
  • place the idler holder in the right side gantry as shown.
  • place the tension brace over the rods as shown
  • run a long (at least 30mm, 40mm is ideal) M4 socket-head cap screw (or pan head) and M4 fender washer through the larger hole in the brace and into the idler holder
  • tighten belt tension

Your X-axis belt tension is now adjustable by the M4 bolt, and will no longer cause binding of your Z-axis.

  • OPTIONAL: run an M3 SHCS and fender washer into the two 3mm holes on the bracket. This should increase the strength of the bracket and keep it from delaminating.

comments.text: Sadly, I make a lot of bad decisions. I bought only the frame, rods and printed parts from Sintron a year ago, with the thought of combining them with the motors, extruder, hotend and board from my OneUp (another mechanical disaster). That's when I designed this. It worked, sort of, but I eventually abandoned the printer. Since then I have merged the best of those parts with a FolgerTech2020 frame kit and splashed out on an E3D V6 and Titan, which actually might get me an OK machine. It's like getting one printer for the price of three!

author: jfpcsmb

description.text:
My Blog entry:
http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.com/ Blog entry by Ax0n:
http://www.h-i-r.net/2010/01/review-master-1500id-speed-dial-lock.html pdf explaining the mechanics:
http://toool.nl/Image:The_New_Master_Lock_Combination_Padlock_V2.0.pdf animation by Michael Huebler:
http://toool.nl/images/e/e1/MhVisualizer_V2.0_p.swf At Easterhegg last weekend I was introduced to this amazing lock (Master Lock 1500iD).
You can enter a combination of up, left, right and down -movements of ANY LENGTH to be your code.
This mechanism is basically a mechanical hash-function of the movements you do.

This is a simplified demonstration-model to illustrate the code-mechanics.
It contains neither the actual locking nor the reset-mechanism nor the mechanism to set your own combination. I just finished the design and did not print it yet. But I made sure it is printable.

Print 4 code-discs, one base-plate and one pin-plate.
Put them together as on the image. You can see the code-discs turn as you slide the upper octaeder around.
Lift the octaeder to see the state of this machine.
Hint: mark one side of each code-weel with a pen.

title: Zelda Laser Etched Bamboo Flash Drive

description.text:
Bamboo flash drive etched with Legend of Zelda theme. Graphics are primarily from A Link to the Past, but the main images on each side are a stain glass design in the gameboy/ Wind waker style and a group silhouette from Twilight Princess.
I did not create these graphics, I just photoshopped and adjusted them for etching and arranged. I also included a file with other small icons so that you could mix and match and make your own.

The flash drive I used was a Bamboo Stick USB 2.0 Flash Drive, with Magnetic Cap. Can be purchased on Amazon or Etsy. Dimensions are 2.36 x 1.1 mm, 1.1 x 0.35 mm, and 2.36 x 0.35 mm.

print_settings.Notes:: The orientation of the files is not shown correctly.  The tool needs to be flipped over and the whistle printed so that the "reed" is at the top.  Accurate (very short) bridging is required for the whistle to print cleanly, but the overhangs are no more than 45%, so this should print easily on any printer.  I first printed this on an original Printrbot Simple cobbled together with zip ties and fishing line and both parts were fully functional.

description.text: I was frustrated by my inability to carry tools with me on carry-on baggage since I fly so often. This is a basic set which allows me to at least turn a screw, hold a nut, and open a beer, and whistle really loudly if truly necessary. The whistle will hold two standard hex bits for use with the tool, but will only work with one bit inserted. There is a standard and metric version. The metric version also has a square cutout for turning a standard drum lug (if you're into that sort of thing). I printed this in PLA with 65% infill, which is the minimum to have a workable tool. I've opened dozens of beers with this tool, but you have to be careful since it's entirely plastic and can either get cut by the cap or broken if you're too rough. The tool and whistle are approximately the length of a standard key, so it fits on a keychain without getting in the way. The hex bits are captured inside the whistle by the keychain when attached.

Printer:

QIDI Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

65% minimum

Notes:

The orientation of the files is not shown correctly. The tool needs to be flipped over and the whistle printed so that the "reed" is at the top. Accurate (very short) bridging is required for the whistle to print cleanly, but the overhangs are no more than 45%, so this should print easily on any printer. I first printed this on an original Printrbot Simple cobbled together with zip ties and fishing line and both parts were fully functional.
Used Solidworks to design the model.

ESPAÑOL

Este es un homenaje a Miguel de Cervantes y su gran obra Don Quijote de la Mancha. Es un portalápices con el principio del texto de Don Quijote.

Model of the Tokyo Japan LDS temple created in Solidworks. Check out my other temple models and let me know which temples you'd like to see! These make great gifts especially for weddings and holidays!

I noticed a problem with using a printed hook instead of a metal thumb ring on a tuba- you can't really lift the tuba by the hook like you can with a thumb ring. So I designed this piece, which is intended to be printed in a typical material (PLA, ABS, PETG, PP, HDPE, etc.), but it does require good bed adhesion, which most printers have. It is designed to slip into place inside the thumb ring, and does not actually clip on, because it doesn't need to due to the circular nature of the ring.

Makerbot rafts will not work on this without lowering the raft-to-model spacing significantly, but other than that, print settings could be just about anything.

This has been tested and it works wonderfully on both my St. Petersburg (Russian) and Manufaktur (German) tubas.
This is my model of a Jumper pack cover I made for a project I am working on I forgot my printing settings but I used PLA and it works great a little tight fit but fits well for me.

title: Quick Change Spool Holder, Mostly Printable w/ Preload bearings

description.text:
I wasn't satisfied with the the printable spool holders I was finding on Thingiverse. They were ether outside roller types or were long rod types, Nether quite fit my needs or space. So I made my own. It features hub mount on ball bearings with an adjustable preload, and quick change mount. The non-printable parts are minimal, and it needs no added supports. The longest part only measures 92.5mm, so it should be printable on any size printer. I have included a wall mount version, and both 1" and 2020 aluminium extrusion mount versions.

It currently only fits a 1kg Makergeeks 210x75mm spool with a 51mm hub bore, offset 19mm on one side. More sizes to come.

Printed parts:
2x Hub_v2
1x Hub_Tube
1x Outer_Hub
1x Outer_Hub_Long
2x Arms of choice, with one mirrored

Required hardware:
4x 606zz bearings
2x M6x30mm hex head bolts
4x M6 nuts
4x M4x10 screws
some M6 washers

Cad files: http://a360.co/2mSrPex

Printer:

i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

35% - 50%

Notes:

The outer hubs have a support bridge in the hex, so no added supports are needed.

description.text:
The default lulzbot mini Y axis on my printer was weak. it cracked. Also when I tensioned the belt it bent the frame.
So I designed this. These are designed to a VERY high tolerance. If you can't print in high quality, you will have some issues and need to do some work to get it to fit.
It uses a set of screws in the back of the rods on the motor mount piece. Insert a nut and use a 20mm m3 screw. tightening the screw increases tension on the Y rods. this keeps the tension of the belt off the frame.

I also re-did the Bearing holders. the stock bearing holders were loose. The bearing MUST be Press-fit. Lulzbot obviously didn't press-fit the original bearings. this is required in these types of bearings to get them to fit right. When I first installed the bearings, they were too tight. I had to chuck an 8mm rod into a drill and wear down the bearing until they could move freely. this is still better than what lulzbot had on there.

comments.text:
Must've been an older generation of Mini you purchased.... The rear Y-rod mount uploaded here obviously was just pulled from Lulzbot as the current revision parts are the same.
What was the issue with the bearings? Loose in holder or loose on rod? They ARE press fit from the factory, but made so that the bearings don't have to be "worn in" as you had to do. Did you buy your printer used or refurbished?
If you bent your frame tightening the belt, you tightened it too much.
comments.author: PerpetualMotion

comments.text:
Brand new from Amazon. We needed it fast.
The bearings were not press fit at all, they had 0.5mm of play, both on the rod and in the bearing holder.
I had to wear them in because of a bad print.
Also, try tightening the belt, the frame will bend without something taking the tension. I saw it every time the y axis moved too.
comments.author: PerpetualMotion

comments.text:
Beware of Amazon, they DO sell used and refurbished (or returned) items as "New." Happens quite frequently actually.
Where exactly was this bend observed, where the cable chain mounts to the frame? I've seen that part move while the Y-axis is in motion but that was due to a clearance issue with the bend radius of the cable chain. It would "bounce" as the links curled against the frame.
The actual purpose of the adjustment screws on the rear has nothing to do with belt tension, it was designed to correct the belt position in the idler, which it does. Older Y-rod mounts were meant to handle that belt tension by the rods bottoming out in the mount.
What exactly did you change with the part? By high tolerance one would conclude that you simply made the holes slightly larger?
Likewise with the bearings, wouldn't high tolerance make them looser?
Have you discussed this at all on the lulzbot forum? A great deal of more experienced individuals that could clarify things in the future.
comments.author: StephS

comments.text: You assume that I am inexperienced. I can assure you that I am not.
comments.author: PerpetualMotion

description.text:
This is a safety knife that uses standard utility blades that you can get at home improvement stores. It's very much a Work In Progress, as I haven't test printed it yet. Feel free to print it and let me know how it works or if changes are needed.

Your printer will need to be fairly accurate for this, as even though the overhangs are only 30 degrees, the clearance for the cover is somewhat tight (100 microns on each side).

Let me know what you think!

Uploaded v2 files on 03/23/2017: Slightly lengthened the blade upon which the design is based. This should improve the internal blade fit. If it still need adjustment, let me know. I left the original files up in case somebody wants to play with them.

Having bought a used Sony 16-50 f/2.8 that came without a hood I thought I'd have a go at making my own. I believe the shape is close to the original (based on photos and thanks to a kind member of the Dyxum forum for measuring his original version) . It seems to work OK even at 16mm without vignetting. The hood has bayonet flanges to fit the lens, but doesn't 'click' into position. Instead, to ensure correct positioning, I have included an indented line to be aligned with the red mark on the lens. It will also fit the lens in reverse.

The hood was designed in OpenSCAD and the source code is included. Depending on your printer calibration and layer height, you might want to change flange_thickness (currently 1.2mm) to ensure a good fit to your lens. Increasing total_height from 50mm to 60mm will give a longer, possibly more effective, hood, though I haven't tested this yet.

title: FlashForge New Creator Pro - Bed Extender - Sized for 8 x 10 Plexiglass

description.text:
I find that on the FlashForge NEW Creator Pro (received November-2016) that parts with large surface areas are difficult to remove from the bed plate. For example the first time I printed out the orange bird house (thingi1351023), I did so on a glass plate, that I clipped to the FlashForge Bed. Because this bird house has such a large contact surface area to the bed, I found it to be very difficult to remove. In the end the glass plate shattered, and in fear of cutting my fingers from the shards of glass, I simply threw the bird house into the garbage.
To remedy, I decided to use plexi-glass, so that I could flex the plate to create a separation between it and the 3d printed object. Locally (at HD) thin plexi-glass can be purchased in 8” x 10” sheets for approximately $4 USD. These sheet are approximately 2mm thick. Then to avoid having to cut the plexi-glass to size, I designed the bed extensions to accommodate the 8 x 10 plexi-glass sheet.
The Bed extensions are small enough to be able to be printed out on top of the original FlashForge Bed. They Bed Extentions are secured into place by using 3mm Wing-Nuts, one for each corner, so a total of 4. From the picture you can see I have the "NEW" Creator Pro Logo is silver/chrome. Therefore this is the 2016 "NEW" Creator Pro. The Bed Extenders accommodate the position of the corner bolts for this model. I do not know, but I would expect that the bed bolt positions are the same for the previous Creator Pro.
To help hold the plexi-glass in position on the bed when printing, small clips are used for clamping. There are 5 slots on each bed extender. The wire clips in the picture are from Dollar Tree; you can purchase a pack of 6 of them for $1. When clamped in place the clips remain outside where the nozzle moves; there is about 10mm clearance. Note: I use Simply3D to slice the parts I print. Therefore starting position of the nozzle is at the front right-hand corner of the bed. If you are using Slic3r or ReplicatorG, the nozzle’s starting position is at the front Left-Hand corner; In this case the wire clip may interfere with the starting position of the nozzle (depending where you place it), you may need to put the clip into a different slot.
As a result I can now print out much larger objects. When I originally printed out the bird house with a glass plate (that shattered), I had scaled it down to 90%, because it came so close to the edge of the FlashForge bed, and I wanted a rim printed. However, with the plexi-glass bed, I was able to print it full size with no worries of hitting the wire clips. It is so nice to be able to print larger objects.

Two other quick notes, I use blue painters tape on the top surface of the plexi-glass, and then liberally apply glue stick to the top of the blue tape. Parts, especially PLA, adhere very well.
Enjoy!

description.text:
The 10mm rods were weak. They were obviously sagging - so I upgraded it to 12mm.

These parts are designed to HIGH tolerance. Print them in ABS, 80% infill. You will need to enclose your printer to keep the parts from warping.

I purchased the 12mm bearings from Lulzbot. The bearings are PRESS-FIT into the holders.
You will also need 2x m3 heat insert, and a m5 LONG heat insert for each rod holder.

You may need to wear in the bearings a bit to get them to move freely.

comments.text: What sort of weight did you stack on your print bed to make the 10mm rods "sag"? They do not sag under any normal use of the machine. More likely they were bent from excess pressure applied either by yourself or during shipping.
comments.author: PerpetualMotion

comments.text:
I used a dial indicator.
Without this upgrade I couldn't get the bed to level.
comments.author: PerpetualMotion

comments.text: Having extensive experience with these machines I believe the rods were bent by another force other than the weight of the bed. Maybe if the rods were 8mm but it takes considerably more force than the weight of the bed to bend a 10mm stainless rod. If it was bent outside of what the bed leveling matrix was capable of compensating for that is a quite a bend and is more than likely shipping damage or abuse. Lulzbot uses these machines in their cluster, if something like what you describe was even possible with normal use of the machine, they would've known and moved to 12mm stock like they did from TAZ5 to TAZ6 on the X-Axis because of the weight of their massive dual extruders.
comments.author: StephS

comments.text: You confuse static with dynamic load. As it accelerates, the rods bend. The tolerances required is much higher than you think. A 0.01mm error would result in 10% error on 0.1mm layer heights. I calibrate my beds to 0.002mm accuracy. To do so, the deflection in the rods needs to meet that number.
comments.author: PerpetualMotion

In this project students will turn a picture into a lithophane using the MakerBot's customizable Lithopane. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:74322

Students were able to successfully create lithophanes using the customizer.

Some students chose animated figures (Bugs Bunny, pokemon) which, because of the small number of colors in the art, did not turn out well.

We also had some trouble with pictures with white backgrouds. These had a very thin first layer which tore when we removed it from the build plate. This was easily fixed with clear packing tape to hold it together.
NGSS

This project is part of an 8th grade science unit on light and touches on subject like transparent, translucent, and opaque.  In this project students were permitted to select any appropriate picture to transform into a lithophane.  The project would work well for other subjects. For example the students could choose a picture representing african american history for Black History Month, or an important woman for Woman's History Month. Or us a family photo to make something for Mother's Day.

• Students first must find a picture. One that has a lot of shades of light and dark works best. A light background is great, but a white background will make a thin first layer which can be fragile. Students could also take their own picture.

  • Students will need an account on Thingiverse, which will require an email address.

  • After logging into thingiverse go to the Lithopane Customizer at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:74322

  • Use Choose File to select the picture and then pick the right setting for Picture Shape and Picture Orientation to match the picture. Look at the blue preview to make sure it's correct.

  • Click on Invert Colors --> this is an important step the students sometimes forget.

  • Open up Adjustments and choose the right Layer Height and Number of Layers. Layer Height is determined by your slicing software. We made ours with a Layer Height of .15 mm and 20 Layers

  • Click on Create Thing. Give it a name. If it's a personal photo you should think carefully whether you want to publish it so that everyone can see it. Thingiverse doesn't let new users publish their work for 24 hours after making an account.

  • It will take about 5 mins for the lithophane to be created. After it's done the STL file can be downloaded.

  • Slice the STL file, we used Cura. Make sure the Layer Height matches the value you used when you made the lithophane. Print with 100% fill using white plastic.
Works best with translucent plastic.

title: Rasplex Zero W IR sensor mount

description.text:
This is only the top part of the case I remixed. I added an ir sensor mount to allow for navigation within rasplex with an ir remote.

How to install rasplex
http://www.rasplex.com/

How to setup the IR sensor(hardware portion only)
https://learn.adafruit.com/using-an-ir-remote-with-a-raspberry-pi-media-center/hardware

setting up GPIO IR receiver
https://sourceforge.net/p/rasplex/wiki/GPIO-IR/

At the time of writing (3/17/17) the raspberry pi zero w was very new. I had to move over some files to get the rasplex to boot up on the zero w. The image will be updated in the future to accommodate the new zero w. This is required if all you see is the rainbow square screen.

youtube.com/watch?v=rvKHefzOTVc

in my opinion the raspberry pi works way better than the chromecast or amazon fire stick

title: 'Hidden' Wheels - Conservation of Angular Momentum Lab

description.text:
'Hidden' Wheels - Conservation of Angular Momentum Lab

In this project/physics lesson, students will be able to test the differences in angular momentum of two different disks of which have differing placements of masses. By testing the wheels of different angular velocities/momenta, students can develop conceptual and experimental knowledge about the ways in which differences in mass placement between the wheels of the same volumes can affect the speed at which it rotates down a ramp - thereby affecting the momentum/moment of inertia.

In thinking about introductory demonstrations to introduce new units of study, this project could be integrated into a unit about circular motion, angular momentum, as well as potential energy. In addition, it can be used as a lab activity in classes such as AP Physics I.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Each print should do fine at .20 resolution, though .1 would produce a finer wheel and have better holes to put screws through.

Infill at 15% works well as the hidden masses of small metal beads will not break through the plastic cover.

Rafting can help with the levelness of the print, though it is not absolutely necessary.
NGSS

This lesson serves as an opportunity to test the concepts of conservation of angular momentum in a 2D space. The instructor conducting this demo should print out enough copies of the each of the two wheels and enough lids for each of them. After printing, the instructor should distribute small, equal masses into each of the openings and seal each wheel and making sure that each group of students gets one of each of the two wheels. After distributing the wheels, the instructor should help students set up a ramp to roll their wheels down. Ideal angles are 30, 45, or 60 degrees and these angles can be recorded for data. Students should be equipped to record time, distance, and mass. Using this quantities, students should be able to calculate the velocity and later calculate the angular momentum of their wheel at specific trials. Objectives
Students will evaluate and discuss the differences in the angular inertia of 3D printed wheels of different densities. Audiences
Grades (7-12)
Ages (12-18) Skills Required
*physics knowledge required: kinematics, dynamics, circular motion Conservation of Angular Momentum Equation: L=mv⊥r, Subjects
Science
Physics Skills Learned (Standards)
HS-PS2-1. Analyze data to support the claim that Newton’s second law of motion describes
HS-PS2-2. Use mathematical representations to support the claim that the total momentum of a system of objects is conserved when there is no net force on the system.

Step 1: 3D Print all necessary wheels for lesson/lab activity
Step 2: Equally distribute materials and wheels to all groups
Step 3: Instruct students about how to engage in lab activity and how to record data
Step 4: Monitor data collection and calculations that students are doing for velocity and angular momentum
Step 5: Allow students to discuss/answer conceptual questions regarding the difference in data collected from one wheel to the other (they should not know of the 3D model the wheels are based on)
Step 6: Class should convene and discuss results
Step 7: Reveal the 'secret' to the differences in angular momentum!

-demonstration/lab space
-3D printer to make wheels
-small bead-like weights (steel balls, nuts, screws - preferably small, dense items)
-Small screws (machine screws preferred, nuts not necessary)
-ramp (could use books or small plastic/wooden boards)
-timer
-rulers/tape measures
-handouts/lab worksheets (to supplement lesson)

description.text:
some modifications to tml's Bunny shaped enclosure for uIEC to allow for new button placement and additional connectors in the latest hardware revision from RETRO Innovations. This is not a very elegant modification:

  • the SIP connector slots could be a bit taller

  • the USB power connector could be moved a bit.

Printer:

Reach 3D

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.15 mm

Infill:

33%

Notes:

This model has thin walls, so good inter-layer adhesion is important or it will tear apart.

I printed this using TecSun PLA+ (slightly tougher PLA than usual) that needs to printed a little hotter than regular PLA.
tml's original STL files were modified by patching and poking holes in the model with OpenSCAD. Source for these modifications are included. It's not an approach I recommend.
